Plainknit¶

Methods for everything sourrunded a plainknit-strickgraph.

This is an classifier module. For this should be some kind of guide, what an classifier should be able to do an some kind of generell coding-, and naming-conventions.

It should contain following methods:

  • find_attributes

  • example_strickgraph_from_attributes

  • strickgraph_classifies(im not sure)

  • attributes_valid(im not sure)

Also it can contain following methods:

  • generate example attribute-compositions

  • alterators to alterate single attributes in a strickgraph

Also contains extra sets of possible attributes, if attributes arent basic types (like ints or strings). Attributes should be explained by a module, class or something similer and arte to be identified my strings.

todo

objects may be more intuitive, than strings. maybe this should be further inspected

todo

add own multisidealteratorclass inside this package, which augment the alterator with a from_attributes_of_plainknit-generator. Remove this generator from baseclass from createcloth.verbesserer

cvar rowstates

set of all possible attributes for single rows

createcloth.plainknit.startsides = {'left', 'right'}¶

possible values for ‘startside’-attribute

Used states¶

createcloth.plainknit.rowstates.decrease: createcloth.plainknit.state.rowstate = decrease¶

row with left and right 3rd position k2tog and else only knits. k2tog is for decrease.

createcloth.plainknit.rowstates.end: createcloth.plainknit.state.rowstate = end¶

endrow with only bindoff

createcloth.plainknit.rowstates.enddecrease: createcloth.plainknit.state.rowstate = enddecrease¶

endrow wizh left and right 3rd position bind2off and else only bindoff

createcloth.plainknit.rowstates.increase: createcloth.plainknit.state.rowstate = increase¶

row with left and right 3rd position yarnover and else only knits. yarnover is for increase.

createcloth.plainknit.rowstates.lefteaves: createcloth.plainknit.state.rowstate = lefteaves¶

row with mainly knit but on zje left side yarnover for increase

createcloth.plainknit.rowstates.leftplane: createcloth.plainknit.state.rowstate = leftplane¶

row with mainly knit but on the left side bindoff for decrease

createcloth.plainknit.rowstates.plain: createcloth.plainknit.state.rowstate = plain¶

row with only knit

createcloth.plainknit.rowstates.righteaves: createcloth.plainknit.state.rowstate = righteaves¶

row with mainly knit but on the right side yarnover for increase

createcloth.plainknit.rowstates.rightplane: createcloth.plainknit.state.rowstate = rightplane¶

row with mainly knit but on the right side bindoff for decrease

createcloth.plainknit.rowstates.start: createcloth.plainknit.state.rowstate = start¶

Startrow with only yarnover

Description of plainknit¶

That means every Strixkgraph only consisting mainly of knit stitches. starting and ending with yarnovers and bindoffs. So that the Strickstueck can increase and extend from row to row, at the sites, there can be yarnover for increase and k2tog for decrease. for strong also possible isthat the sderow hs on both sides yarnover or bindoff.

createcloth.plainknit.create_example_strickgraphs.create_stitchnumber_to_examplestrick(q, startside='right')¶

Creates a mapping of a stitches_per_line via class_idarray to possible linetypes and their real stitches_per_line. The stitches-per-line are saved as class_idarray. This is to compare different stitches-per-line which are comparable, if they are widened or shortened.

Parameters

q (Iterable[ Tuple[ linetype, ... ] ]) – Possible strickgraph represented from linetypes

Returns

Mapping of id from stitches-per-line to possible linetypes and their real stitches-per-line

Return type

Dict[ class_idarray, List[ Tuple[Iterable[linetypes], Iterable[int]] ] ]

createcloth.plainknit.create_example_strickgraphs.order_to_nearest_neighbours(list_of_linelength, increase=True)¶
Return type

Dict[ (int,int), Iterable[ int ] ]

Returns

mapping of which linelength is neighboured to which one depending on linelengths and changedline. Gives only increase or decrease depending on input ‘increase. linelength are described by integers
